done  Hi liaosaur! Great job! Many thanks  Grate job! Many thanks  Thanks for the contribution!!!! very helpful  Thanks for the report. I've just pushed the fix.  Thanks dude!!!  Many thanks for the contribution, never had that problem before, but any improvement is welcomed

thanks again  I merged SUHAR1K patch

madjapahit, can you check if the problem persists?  Can't resolve domain name. Maybe some regular expression escaping bug?   Thanks for the fix!!!   Merged patch.  Hello r0p0s3c , thanks for the contribution,

Would you please change your format string syntax? You are using the classic syntax with %, and I'm currently using the new "{}".format syntax in the whole project. Check this

https://docs.python.org/3.1/library/string.html#format-examples

Please, I'd like to keep the code consistent.
 Thanks r0p0s3c !!
  Thanks !
  Upgrade your version and give it a try
  Welcome vlohacks, thanks for the contribution

I'll test the path and merge as soon as possible.
 Please, remove this line from the commit

self.output.newLine("\n" + str(self.arguments.forceExtensions))
 Done! Great work!
  I updated the readme with the note
 No problem dude, you're welcome.

Yes, I did it on purpose because I thought it's more hackable this way and you can use it the way you want. What if you want to use the passed extensions at the begining or in the middle of the word? You can't do that in the other way... 
  There is no such option in dirsearch. 

In those cases I go to the "reports" folder and use the "grep" command to look for what I want (and "grep -v" for what I don't). And if I want to do it while dirsearch is running, I "tail -f" the report file.
  nice contribution!!
  Yes, it's a good idea. I'm planning to add some sort of wordlist template engine. I'll try to finish that new feature soon.
  Get the last version from master branch, modify the default.conf and uncomment the following line:

#save-logs-home = True

Give it a try and let me know if it's working
  Hello qwhj, thanks for the submission.

The Fuzzer.getPath() method is unused in the latest version of dirsearch.

https://github.com/maurosoria/dirsearch/commit/9764c6e27d043de2d0b2d399557604c2e2991c86
 You don't have to say sorry, it was a nice catch :)
  Yes, I've removed them because they were too big (slow downloading/cloning).

Anyway, you can still get them from this commit: https://github.com/maurosoria/dirsearch/tree/db29b6fe2201b6e9f5c50f707cb4b93f1c985ab6/db

I'm collecting different dictionaries in order to open a different repository with them (with a few scripts for joining/modifying them). So all suggestions/submits are welcome.

Thanks in advance

  check now please
  Why this change? I don't understand the purpose of this patch. Directories can be dotted too.

Furthermore, some php CMSs, force you to use routes like this:
http://www.example.com/cms/index.php/users/

In this cases, you have a route that is a file, so this patch won't work.
 No problem dude, thanks for the colaboration. If you have another suggestion, feel free to open an issue :+1:  
  Check my comment in this issue:
https://github.com/maurosoria/dirs3arch/issues/10

Would that feature fit your needs?

The problem with this patch, It's that won't fit my needs, because it'd just duplicate a lot of lines of the dictionary (something that made me hate dirbuster in the past... and that's why dirs3arch exists). I like in this way because it will only test the files that i've specified in the dictionary.

But, you're not the first person who wants compatibility with fuzzdb/dirbuster dictionaries, so I'd be adding a new argument switch for this mode in this commit (and a new line in default.conf, soy you'd be able to set this mode as default behaviour) , so everyone will be happy.

Do you agree with this? Any other suggestion?
  Merged :D 
  Thanks bro :D
  Thanks dude, merged
  Hi sammbertram,

Actually you're not the first person who complains about this. I'm thinking about adding an argument switch to support an alternate type of dictionary ("dirbuster like" dictionaries). What do you think?
  apparently it's a bug, could you provide more info? I need to reproduce the error.
 fixed

Hi Mauro,
the last reales you've released is the year  2016  (v0.3.7). But since then many improvements have been made, so many commit.

Cuddly can you release a new version? So I put it in BackBox.

Thank you
Andrea  I've recently come across a bunch of websites that annoyingly return empty 200 responses (see screenshot)
![screen shot 2017-06-01 at 15 00 03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2960928/26665299/fae71cd2-46db-11e7-8be0-794ade36d5cf.png)


I added a `--suppress-empty` flag that stops 0 byte responses from being logged to the console    allows setting a delay in seconds between requests: ``--delay n``  First, thank you for your work.

Please add FreeBSD to the list of operating systems under which to use _get_terminal_size_linux() function:

```
diff lib/utils/TerminalSize.py ~/dirsearch.git/trunk/lib/utils/TerminalSize.py
40c40
<     if current_os in ['Linux', 'Darwin', 'FreeBSD'] or current_os.startswith('CYGWIN'):
---
>     if current_os in ['Linux', 'Darwin'] or current_os.startswith('CYGWIN'):
42a43
>         print("default")
```

Also _print("default")_ on line 43 seems to be a forgotten debug message.  In the beginning I wanted to correct an error in the url, but it seemed to me that it is better to leave it in primary view that will display the structure of the resource. I do not know whether the error is in Linux.  By default, dirsearch queries by IP, with the hostname in the Host header.

This is fine for most webservers, but some hosts (like CDNs) can get picky about this and reject requests that are made by IP address.

I added a boolean -b / --request-by-hostname argument that will override the default behaviour and instead query by hostname  trying with complex URL to bruteforce app function :

http://sub.sub.sub.domain.net/func/service.dll?fid=415&f=/myfunc/loginverify&checkif=

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

And for traceback :

Target: http://sub.sub.sub.domain.net/func/service.dll?fid=415&f=/myfunc/loginverify&checkif=

 { "content-length": 0, "path": "/.CSV", "status": 301 }

 Nice, thanks a lot!!
  Hi, 

Like your tool very much, thanks for the effort, it is a cool successor for the abandoned DirBuster tool. I missed one feature to use a plain dirbuster wordlist with extensions and added it, maybe you also find it useful. 
Added option -f / --force-extenisons to brute force a plain wordlist with all extensions (like in dirbuster) without needing the %EXT% wildcard.

Regards Florian 
 Hi,
Removed the line, sry for the late reply
  Please document somewhere this. It took me half day to realize, I need to add %EXT% on line endings in dictionary file to check extensions. Please...
 Thanks!
By the way, if you use **example%EXT%** and add **/** to extensions, it can be one line in dict (and need to add dot to prefix every extension, like **/,.asp,.aspx**).
  Hey,

Often times you'll get a series of dirnames that return garbage. Sometimes they'll look like:

/offers-orlando/
/offers-mexico/
/offers-newyork/

etc..

What would be the best way to be able to exclude these sorts of directories? I'm opening an issue because I'd like other thoughts. I'm not sure if there should be an exclude by regex or exclude by simply checking for a substring in the path. Thoughts?
  https://larsjung.de/h5ai/
  Hello and thank you for this tool!

I was wondering if you could implement a system that would allow us to use dictionaries specific to a language. For example, dirseach could by default work on a common dictionary (with strings like .svn, .git, backup, etc) as well as an English dictionary (with strings like schedule, gallery...), and we could also add an option in the command line (for example, --language ISOCODE) to test for language-specific strings from dictionaries located in the db/ folder (for example, db/dicc_ISOCODE.txt).

Thank you for your answer.
  Hi Mauro,
I'm a developer of BackBox Linux. Remember?! :D

Now the software will automatically generate the log, to create a correctly Debian package would be appropriate that the logs were generated in the user's folder.

Otherwise the script must be executed with the permissions of SUDO. Otherwise it generates the error "Permission denied: '/usr/share/DirSearch/logs".

You can change the log salvage path? In Python you can use: os.path.expanduser ("~")

Thanks
Andrea

  For some reason, dirsearch begins all JSON report files with a bunch of NULL characters.
This confuses some JSON decoders, like the one included in Python.
 Looks much better - thanks a lot!

  When configured for use multiple threads sometimes doesnt find resources.

It'easy to check. Just launch the program against a web server with known resources and with a medium size dictionary file.

Try it with "-t 1" and with "-t 20" several times. You'll see that "-t 20" option sometimes returns less hits.

  Modifies paths that could be considered recursive by dirs3arch:
# Web server resources:

www.url.com/web/ - 404
www.url.com/web - 302
www.url.com/web/help/ - 404
www.url.com/web/help - 302
www.url.com/web/help/index.html - 200
# Dictionary file

web/
web
help
help/
index.%EXT%

$ ./dirs3arch -u www.url.com -r -e "html"

Before change: Recursive are only those paths that ends with ("/")

www.url.com/web - 302

After change: Recursive are those paths that are not files (don't contains a dot) and are not just "/" chars.

www.url.com/web - 302
www.url.com/web/help - 302
www.url.com/web/help/index.html - 200
 Sorry, you're right.

Best regards,

  When reading the dictionary file any word that doesnt ends with char "/" or doesnt contains "%EXT%" is added two times:
1) just as is
2) with a "/" appended

So, if the dictionary file is like this:
# DictionaryFile

web
index.%EXT%

and the command is called this way:
$ ./dirs3arch -w DictionaryFile -e "php,html" -u url

the fuzzed dictionary will be:

web
web/
index.php
index.html

The result is the same we'll get with this dictionary file:
# DictionaryFile

web
web/
index.%EXT%

The reason for this change is that, sometimes, web servers return a 404 when the directory resource is hit but the url resource without "/" returns a differente code what it usually means that it contains more resources...

It's not complicated to create a new dictionary file for this kind of webs but I prefer dirs3arch doing the work for me...
 Sure,
that solution would be perfect.

Thank you very much.
David.

  The options of dirs3arch include a space when specifying comma delimited extensions. The script needs extensions passed in without comma's. Just to help people that don't realise at first, I've removed the space in the help output.
  Hi. I had a suggestion for dirs3arch that would hopefully make it more intuitive and flexible to use. 

A problem right now is that dirs3arch requires custom wordlists, due to the %EXT% being included to replace the extension. This is problematic because it increases the size of the wordlists by double, and you can't just quickly download a wordlist to use but have to determine how precisely to use the extension with %EXT%. 

Might I suggest using a simple wordlist and leaving it up to the user to append the extension.. for example:

```
./dirs3arch.py -u 'foo' -w bar -e /,.aspx
```

This could then append / and then .aspx to the wordlists. This also allows for the default behaviour to NOT have an extension which is nice for REST-style URLs. The potential confusion with this is the explicit inclusion of the . before the aspx. In the fork in my repo I've made some modifications for this (albeit an older version), that allow for this usage but it should be quite simple to implement. 

Anyways, thanks for the tool!

Sam
 Hey. That would be excellent! It caught me back in November when I couldn't get it working, but finally realised. I think the %EXT% feature would be most suited if you want to replace text within the dictionary word. 

A lot of dictionaries I use are from fuzzdb, and they don't have the %EXT%, and would have to add them in manually. In addition, lets say I brute with .asp, and then realise I want to do .aspx later. If I use the %EXT% dictionaries, it will automatically brute the "/" twice as that is a default.
